content.description: Waterfront is the left most route on the right wall just off the gully.  You kind of have to climb around the large log.  It is short but not a bad climb.
content.protection: Waterfront has 2 bolts for anchors.  Don't recall the gear situation.

content.description: This short route is on the face to left of Beach Blanket Bingo and to the right of Red Argyle. Start off with some bouldery moves (the 'crux' of the climb)and go up easier ledges above.
content.protection: Nuts and cams.  Can TR this climb as well. Anchor off big tree at top of ledge.
content.location:
Look for the flake up and left for first hands.

Easy walk off to the West, but can also get down to the East.

content.description: This climb is the bolted line just right of the fallen log, that blocks Waterfront.  It is well protected and climbs easily.  It consists of good ledges and edges and is pretty consistent.
content.protection: There are 2 bolts for anchors and I believe it needs 4 draws for the route.

content.description: Just right of Beach Blanket Bingo, is a face with anchors.  This is a nice ladder climb for kids.
content.protection: Build an anchor.  No other protection on it, but it is short and easy enough to allow a solo.

content.description:
Start just left of

His Feet Smell/Reach the Beach

.  Climb up and diagonal slightly left, intersecting a large crack system near its top.  Step left and climb face past a bolt to the top, ending a few feet right of the anchors for the (currently) chopped "unknown" route right of

Waterfront

.  Perhaps the longest route on the crag, this is a must do for the Beachball aficionado  (it would at least keep the moss from growing back).  The bolt was added after the FA to make it suitable for 5.7 leaders.
content.protection: Cams from 3/4 to 2 inches (look for horizontal placements), medium nuts, draws.  Probably safest to walk off; as of this writing, the anchors for the "unknown" route had only one quicklink.
content.location:
Find

Reach the Beach

in the Ruckmans' or Calderone's guides.

content.description: SPF 25 is left of the large gully. It climbs a nice small roof with reachy holds.  It then climbs a nice angling finger crack.
content.protection: SPF 25 protects with small to medium size gear.  The anchor requires medium to larger size gear to set up.

content.description: Attack the arete and the roof straight on.
content.protection: Some horizontal cracks for placement, set your own anchors.

content.description: Sneak-a-Peak Arete starts left of the obvious arete in the center of the right face.  It traverses right to get to the arete after the overhang ends, and then climbs straight up, utilizing both sides of the arete and thin edges.
content.protection: Sneak-a-Peak Arete has no fixed anchors and it isn't easy to set up an anchor, but it can be done.  There is no fixed gear on the route and it is very runout.

content.description: Don't do it. Cobwebs galore. Dirt galore.  Rotten rock galore.  But, if you choose to ignore me, Rubble Without A Cause is the wide crack on the right of the left face.
content.protection: Rubble Without A Cause protects with large gear.  It has no fixed anchors so bring gear and slings.

content.description: Rip's Roof climbs a small roof just left of the large roof on the western half of the wall.  It is typically in the stream, so rock-hop over there.  The roof is cake and the crack above is even easier.  This is a fun climb if you are starting to climb roofs, and want to do so with no fear.
content.protection: Rip's Roof can utilize the anchors for the climb just to the west (Outside It's America), and it protects well with large hexes and medium to large nuts for the upper face.

content.description: Reach the Beach climbs the rightward trending horizontal cracks climbing the wall avoiding the roof by going to the right of it.  It is 30 feet or so to the right of the gully.
content.protection: Reach the Beach has no fixed anchors, so bring gear.

content.description: On the right side of the crag, start near a tree on dry ground.  Move left to a short dihedral and then left again underneath a roof.  Pull over the roof, and you are in hiking territory once again.  A fun but strange little route that is best to lead - it wanders too much to make toproping appealing.
content.protection: Stoppers, maybe some cams to 1.5"

content.description: This is the bolted route in the middle of the wall.
content.protection:
2 bolts and I think a 2 bolt anchor.

The anchor bolts were loose, so I backed them up in the nearby crack.

This is easy to setup as a TR.

content.description: Climbs the crack just right of the gully left of Waterfront. The crack has two bushes growing out of it. The first 1/3 of the climb is unprotected but the climbing is EASY. Very dirty!
content.protection: Small gear to #1 Camalot.  There are no anchors at the top.  I used a tree about 10' back from the top of the wall. First 1/3 of the route is unprotected.

content.description: 50 feet left of Red Argyle is a beautiful obvious finger crack in a corner.  The climb starts directly out of the water, but you can traverse in from the right easily enough.  The bushes at the beginning of the corner are annoying but not as bad as they look, and the upper section is a joy.  This is an excellent route.
content.protection: Stoppers, cams to 2"

content.description: His Feet Smell climbs the face 20 feet right of the gully. It climbs the cracked face to the roof and pops it right at the center.  It has a reachy crux, and is worth stopping at Beachball to climb.
content.protection: His Feet Smell has a 2-bolt anchor.  Small to medium gear protects it, and maybe a cam just over the roof.

content.description: Buddha Babies On the Beach climbs the left-trending thin crack on the east side of Beachball.  It joins up with Across From the Wave at the hole, and continues to the top.
content.protection: Buddha Babies On the Beach does not have fixed anchors, so bring your gear to the top.  It protects with small to medium gear and a #2 Camalot for the hole works wonders.

content.description: This route is on the east face of the eastern half.  It climbs close to the arete, popping a small bulge at the top.  It is easy down below, and has jugs to pull the crux.
content.protection: The anchor takes creativity to secure as the rock on top is ugly, bring large slings and a variety of gear.  I used a couple of runners on a small tree and a couple of nuts and hexes.  If you lead this, it is terribly runout with only a couple of pieces to be placed right near the crux, which is the roof at the top.

content.description: At the extreme right end of the cliff, climb the large dihedral 30' or so right of Red Argyle.  Very easy, very short, but fun low angle jug hauling.
content.protection: Stoppers, maybe some cams.Very short so a good solo.

content.description: Across From The Wave climbs the left-most crack on the left face, to a small ledge and over a hole.  Not long but a good practice trad route.
content.protection: Across From The Wave protects with small to medium gear with a large cam (#2 Camalot) to protect the hole from the ledge.  You will need gear and slings for the anchor up top.
